Maui is it's a crossplatform mobile UI framework well I guess not just mobile
because you can make iOS Android Windows and Mac OS apps all in C and they're all
totally native uh the way this technology Works under the hood is every time iOS comes out with a new release
the engineers at Microsoft take that iOS SDK and wrap every single API so that we can access them in C uh likewise with
Android every time a new Android release comes out the engineers of Microsoft wrap that up so that we can access it in C and that way we can still build a
totally native app so what I mean by that is when you click compile you're compiling down to all the native bits
when you run it on these devices the phone has no idea you wrote your code in C and with that we get a lot of the
Native performance benefits we get a lot of the Native UI controls and defaults so you have a uh very familiar looking
feel on Android versus iOS and it's one of the few services that does it like
that so for example flutter um you're actually not using any of the Native UI for flutter flutter gives you a blank
canvas and you literally just it just paints on controls it it looks like it's uh the native UI it's really not but
with donet Maui under the hood it's all just the same apis that if you ever made an app in Objective C Swift or Java or
cotlin it's the same thing um the only slight difference on those apis is we do
see sharify them a little bit so you know the Java World they still love their get set methods whereas we have
properties so we'll we'll take those and turn them into properties instead of leaving them as uh get inter ceter
methods and we might take a string and make it an enum but for all intensive purposes if you ever done any iOS or
Android development in Java cotlin uh or objective c Swift pretty much the same
idea and also it's crossplatform meaning we
can write our code once and then that same code will run natively on every single platform that we see here and
what I mean by that is if I in my code say Center a button in the middle of the screen well when I compile that down to
Android that button compiles down to a native Android widget button whereas when I compile that down on iOS that
compiles down to an uh UI button which is the native iOS control so you get the
same look and feel and this is one of the things I love about it because
Android and iOS they have slightly different design paradigms and that's what our users are used to so if you're

IPv6 IP address and that's a valid email I had no idea uh so email is crazy

while that thing is sending well on the button the properties called is enabled so you have to set is enabled to false
but in your view model the property is called is busy and that'll be true so no worries you
